See 24 Astounding Images From the Wildlife Photographer of the Year Contest—and Vote for Your Favorite
The public will choose the winner of the People’s Choice award in a vote that runs from February 4 to March 18
In a flash of purple feathers, a rarely-seen bird snatches a cicada from the ground and holds the insect triumphantly in its beak. A superpod of dolphins swims in an immense wave across the sea. A rescued baby pangolin nuzzles into a blanket at a rehabilitation center.
These scenes and more reveal the splendor, curiosities and trials of the natural world that play out each day, often far from the public eye. In the annual Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition, developed and produced by the Natural History Museum in London, photographers put these hidden moments on display.
More than 60,000 images vied for recognition in this year’s contest, representing photographers from 113 countries and territories. The museum announced the esteemed category winners in October and revealed a gallery of 100 photos to be honored in a museum exhibition. But one award has yet to be bestowed.
Now anyone can play the role of a judge for a contest so prestigious that it’s known informally as the “Oscars of wildlife photography.” For the People’s Choice award, 24 photos are in contention—and the public will decide the winner.
“Whether showcasing fascinating behavior or platforming a powerful story, this year’s selection of images is truly exceptional,” says Douglas Gurr, director of the Natural History Museum in London. “We can’t wait to see which one will be chosen as the public’s favorite.”
The contest’s images seek not just to reveal the beautiful and lighthearted moments of nature, but to unveil the sometimes harsh realities that affect the wild world. Predation, conflict with humans, climate change, pollution and land development add pressure to animals’ lives, and these themes are present in many of the nominated photographs.
Voting is open now and ends on March 18 at 9:00 A.M. Eastern Standard Time. Marvel at all the options below, then pick your favorite.
The winner—and the four runners-up—will be announced by the museum on March 25, and the photograph with the most votes will be displayed alongside the other contest winners in the Wildlife Photographer of the Year exhibition in London.
Here are the 24 photos in the running for the honor.
Ready to Pounce by Joseph Ferraro
Ambush bugs are named for their hunting style—they lie in wait until prey draws near, then suddenly attack. This one, near photographer Joseph Ferraro’s front door in Ferndale, Michigan, sat on a flower for its predatory vigil.
Once an unlucky insect comes close, the bug snatches it with its front legs and inserts venom that immobilizes the prey. This fluid also serves a digestive purpose: It turns the prey’s insides into liquid, allowing the ambush bug to drink it.
Along for the Ride by Chris Gug
Why would a crab sit atop a jellyfish? Maybe it’s using the jelly as a form of transportation or hiding from predators among the larger animal’s tentacles. Perhaps, drifting along on the bell of the creature, the crab gets a good vantage point for spotting small fish to snack on.
This scenario, which raises more questions than answers, played out in the darkness of the Lembeh Strait at nighttime in North Sulawesi, Indonesia. Photographer Chris Gug captured the juvenile swimming crab as it hitched an inexplicable ride.
Flying Rodent by Josef Stefan
Young lynxes often play with their food—and doing so might even help them hone their hunting skills. This wildcat in Torre de Juan Abad, Ciudad Real, Spain, spent about 20 minutes tossing a rodent in the air and catching it before ultimately chowing down on the tiny creature. To photographer Josef Stefan, who watched from behind a wildlife blind, it looked like the rodent was flying.
A Fragile Future by Lance van de Vyver
Pangolins are the world’s only mammals that are completely covered in scales. When threatened, they curl into a tight ball with the sharp scales pointing out as protective armor. But this unique trait also makes pangolins vulnerable—poachers kill the animals because their scales are used for traditional medicines in eastern Asia, and their meat is coveted as a delicacy. As a result, pangolins, which live across Asia and Africa, are the most trafficked wild mammal in the world.
This baby pangolin’s mother was saved from trafficking but died shortly after giving birth. At a rescue center in South Africa, as the baby nestled into a warm blanket, photographer Lance van de Vyver captured this image, which demonstrates “both the resilience of life and the ongoing problem of the illegal wildlife trade,” per a statement.
Dark Knight by Prasenjeet Yadav
Animals with melanism have excessive amounts of the pigment melanin, resulting in darker coloration. This tiger has what’s known as pseudo-melanism, in which his black stripes are wider than usual, sometimes making him appear completely dark, despite having some orange patches.
Known as T12, the tiger was once the only male in the Similipal Tiger Reserve in Odisha, India—and only a handful of females wandered the protected area alongside him ten years ago. T12 has now become the father of several new generations of tigers, promoting the cats’ survival in the reserve. Prasenjeet Yadav tracked the male for months and photographed him with hidden cameras.
Precious Cargo by Thomas Hunt
This cellar spider is an attentive mother—she protects the case of eggs for as long as one month, until the tiny, transparent spiderlings crawl out.
The spider mom got a little help from photographer Thomas Hunt, who found her in his sister’s bedroom in Southampton, England. Noticing the eggs, he coaxed the spider onto a piece of wood and relocated her to the garage, so she could raise her young there.
Cellar spiders, sometimes known as daddy longlegs (like many other types of spiders and arachnids), can carry 13 to 60 eggs in a sack, writes the photographer on Instagram.
Into the Furnace by Mogens Trolle
Campsites at Kaeng Krachan National Park in Thailand have been welcoming some unusual visitors in recent years: sun bears, the smallest bear species. They’re drawn by the possibility of finding an easy meal, and this bear, with a butterfly perched on its nose, is rummaging through the trash.
As the sign in the photograph reads, Mogens Trolle notes in a statement that this situation is an example of evolution—humans have disturbed the bear’s habitat, and the animal is responding.
A Fleeting Moment by Lior Berman
The rufous-vented ground cuckoo, a furtive and mysterious bird species, snags a meal on the floor of a Costa Rican rainforest.
Its hunting strategy is to follow a bevy of army ants. These relatively large ants feed in massive hordes that number in the thousands or millions and travel along the forest floor to gobble up other arthropods. The bird isn’t interested in eating the army ants, but it watches their advance, keeping an eye out for any other creatures crawling away from the swarm.
“This secretive predator is rarely seen and even more rarely photographed,” according to a statement. “It thrives in the chaos of the undergrowth and relies on split-second decisions and perfect timing.”
Here, photographer Lior Berman caught the elusive cuckoo as it grabbed a cicada.
Family Rest by Christopher Paetkau
A mother polar bear and her three cubs rest on the ground in summer, taking a break from their journey along the coast of Canada’s Hudson Bay in this aerial shot by Christopher Paetkau.
During the summers, when the bay is not frozen over, polar bears must retreat to land and search for food there. When sea ice returns, they can once more hunt their favored prey: seals. But with climate change, sea ice is melting earlier in spring and forming later in fall. This can make it harder for the polar bears to find food—though one bear population in Norway has actually been gaining weight.
Portrait of Extinction by Adam Oswell
In just one year, rangers collected this enormous mountain of wildlife snares from Uganda’s Murchison Falls National Park. These traps—coils of wire, cable or rope meant to capture animals—are used by subsistence hunters and poaching syndicates. Snares also produce tens of millions of pounds of wasted meat each year.
Photojournalist Adam Oswell, alongside community volunteers and Uganda Wildlife Authority rangers, joined a weeklong effort to put together this display to communicate the problem of snares.
Uniqueness by Daniela Anger
Daniela Anger spotted this unusual river otter feasting on a catfish in Mato Grosso do Sul, in Brazil’s southern Pantanal region. Its pale color comes from a condition called leucism, or a partial loss of pigmentation.
Because their lighter color doesn’t camouflage as well as natural hues, leucistic animals can face a greater risk of predation. But, for the time being, when Anger watched the otter, it seemed very comfortable being on view.
Hold Me Tightly by Dvir Barkay
Brown-throated sloths are famous for their slow speeds. During a weeklong observation at Costa Rica’s La Selva Biological Station, photographer Dvir Barkay saw this mother and her baby move between merely three trees. They mostly stayed high in the canopy.
Here, the mother sloth shelters her young from a rainy downpour, cradling the sleeping little one in her arms.
Above and Below by Charles Davis
When Australian photographer Charles Davis set up a camera trap in Tasmania, he was hoping to get snapshots of quolls—spotted, carnivorous marsupials with long tails. But after one month of taking images, another creature grabbed his attention.
Here, a mother and a joey brushtail possum climb on a branch, seeming to mirror each other’s movements. The pair appeared in several of Davis’ shots as they foraged for leaf buds, insects and other foods.
Dancing in the Headlights by Will Nicholls
In Canada’s Jasper National Park, two bear cubs playfight in silhouette on a road, backlit by the headlights of a car. They look to be dancing together, creating a delightful scene that also highlights a real risk to the animals.
For instance, near Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming, a car caused the death of the “world’s most famous grizzly” in October 2024—and her cub suffered the same fate the following May. Many roads in and around the park reduce speed limits to minimize collisions, but multiple bears are still killed by cars each year in the greater Yellowstone ecosystem.
Beauty Against the Beast by Alexandre Brisson
Photographer Alexandre Brisson spent ten hours driving to a bird sanctuary in Walvis Bay, Namibia, where he found this flock of flamingoes at sunset.
Even in this natural area, signs of human development are present—power lines stretch across the refuge, and Brisson could smell the stench of a nearby dump site. But the flamingoes’ beauty stood out, highlighted by the colorful sky and their graceful flight.
He clicked the shutter just as a pair of birds flew through the center of the shot, perfectly framed by the power lines.
Swirling Superpod by Cecile Gabillon
Cecile Gabillon’s fisheye lens wasn’t wide enough to capture the full size of this dolphin superpod—an enormous group of spinner dolphins chasing lanternfish off the Pacific coast of Costa Rica.
It was, she says in a statement, one of the most amazing encounters she’s ever experienced. Working hard to keep up with the dolphins’ swimming pace, Gabillon almost forgot to come up for air.
Bond in Motion by Lalith Ekanayake
Not one but two sets of eyes stared into Lalith Ekanayake’s lens as an adult and an infant lion-tailed macaque raced toward the photographer.
The scene played out in the city of Valparai in the Western Ghats, India. As the mother hurried along a path in front of lush vegetation, the infant clung to her underside, peering out from her fur.
Lion-tailed macaques are endangered, and they’re among the most threatened macaques in the world, per a statement. Human activity is chipping away at their habitat, fragmenting it into disconnected parts that isolate populations from one another. According to the statement, the photographer thought this picture represented the monkeys’ resilience.
Marvelous Spatuletail by Dustin Chen
As it feeds from a flower, a male marvelous spatuletail hummingbird puts its dramatic tail on display, which it uses to attract females. The long feathers end in purple-black “spatules” that only the males possess.
“Hummingbirds are one of my favorite subjects to photograph … playing vital roles to keep the ecosystems healthy and balanced,” photographer Dustin Chen, who watched this bird during a trip to Pomacochas, Peru, writes on Instagram. “Glad to speak for them using my photos and raise awareness of their status.”
Habitat destruction and human population growth have restricted the bird’s range, cornering it into a small region of the Andes Mountains in northern Peru. The species was considered endangered from 2000 to early 2023. Then, it was reclassified as near threatened, despite a decreasing population trend.
Never-Ending Struggle by Kohei Nagira
Male sika deer compete for females in the fall, hitting their antlers together in battle to determine dominance. These fights can get aggressive, and sometimes, they end in death—for instance, if the antlers become interlocked.
That’s what happened with this male deer in Hokkaido, Japan, photographed by Kohei Nagira. According to a statement, a local fisherman said the deer had been carrying around the full body of its rival for several days before the head detached. The image shows that “life and death bound together,” per the statement. This deer, despite being bogged down, foraged grass and branches to survive the winter.
Couple’s Camouflage by Artur Tomaszek
Broad-headed bark spiders are not easy to spot. Having evolved to look like an unassuming bump on a twig, the spiders are masters of camouflage.
Photographer Artur Tomaszek had a difficult time finding this pair in Phuket, Thailand. He spotted them at night, on their web, then returned during the day to try to relocate them on the nearby tree bark.
Here, the male sits on top of the female, which is much larger, even though she hasn’t fully matured—the species is sexually dimorphic, meaning the males and females look different from each other. Male broad-headed bark spiders are around one-fourth the size of females, and this one has climbed atop a female’s abdomen. He will wait there until she molts into an adult and is ready to mate.
The Final Portrait by Nima Sarikhani
In this close-up shot, a young polar bear looks into the camera while on a hunting trip with its mother. This portrait, by photographer Nima Sarikhani, might be the last image of this cub alive—conflict with humans led to the bear’s death.
The cub and its mother wandered toward a human gathering on Norway’s Svalbard archipelago, where the people forced them away. Not long after, the mother was found dead with internal injuries, and police shot the cub because they deemed it to be aggressive.
Solar Waves by Francesco Russo
In an arrangement that looks like a river system from above, solar panels coat the landscape, with gaps built around pasture dividers.
Photographer Francesco Russo captured this aerial image near Cambridge, England, as part of a research project to document the ways that industry and nature interact near the River Severn—Britain’s longest river—and its estuary.
Beak-to-Beak by Ponlawat Thaipinnarong
For hours at a time, photographer Ponlawat Thaipinnarong lay on the ground amid rice paddies, watching birds.
Specifically, he was looking at families of sarus cranes in Buri Ram, Thailand’s Huai Chorakhe Mak Non-Hunting Area. Parent cranes would feed their chicks during the day, then, in the evenings, settle into their nests. After this one-week-old chick was carefully cleaned by its parent, the pair tenderly touched their beaks together, and Thaipinnarong captured the sweet moment.
A Leap Into Adulthood by Peter Lindel
The 31-inch gap between their nest and this wooden beam seemed like a giant leap for these three young kestrels. The birds had hatched in Dortmund, Germany—and photographer Peter Lindel could see it all from his living room.
From April to July 2023, he watched a pair of kestrels court each other, then ultimately raise their young until the little birds fledged.
It took almost a week of deliberation for the birds to seemingly gather the nerve to make the jump to the beam. Then, they spent another week around Lindel’s house before making their own way in the world.

This New Samurai Exhibition Will Challenge Your Understanding of the Japanese Warrior Class
Silk screens, women’s firefighting robes and a Darth Vader costume are among the more than 280 unexpected items that are on display at the British Museum
When visiting a museum to learn about the samurai, one might expect to see suits of armor and elegant swords. The British Museum’s new exhibition, “Samurai,” which runs through May 4, does indeed showcase katanas (long swords), daisho (sets of paired swords) and jinbaori (samurai surcoats). But the rest of the more than 280 items on display will, as the Telegraph’s art critic Alastair Sooke puts it, “[challenge] everything you thought you knew about the Japanese warriors.”
“Samurai,” curated by Japanese art scholar Rosina Buckland, aims to expand and challenge the collective memory of Japan’s most iconic warriors and paint a more complex picture of their 1,000-year history.
“This [exhibition] is trying to say that there’s a lot that is misunderstood and based on myth,” Buckland told the Guardian’s Dalya Alberge in November. “They were warriors in the beginning, but there was a balance between the military and the literary and the artistic.”
The samurai, long known in Japan as bushi, emerged around the tenth century as fierce soldiers-for-hire for wealthy landowners. By the 12th century, through a period of unrest and warfare, the samurai grew in political power and established Japan’s first shogunate, or military government. Under the shogunate, samurai were no longer subordinate fighters but the elite ruling class, and as such, their garb and weapons evolved to match their status.
One such item on display in the “Samurai” exhibition is a 1519 helmet adorned with gold lacquer and massive iris leaves, a style meant to evoke both fear and wealth. These extravagant wardrobe details are among the elements that the Telegraph affectionately calls “dandyish as hell.”
By the 17th century, Japan was enjoying an era of peace, known as the Edo period, which rendered the military prowess of samurai less relevant. Instead of riding into battle, Artnet’s Richard Whiddington writes, samurai “served as government workers, scholars and patrons of the arts” for hundreds of years. “Samurai” includes paintings and botanical studies done by samurai lords and their families. It also features interior decorations, such as an ornate folding screen depicting a 12th-century battle.
Perhaps one of the show’s most surprising artifacts comes from the Edo period. It is a woman’s firefighting jacket, red with gold motifs depicting waves, that would have been worn by a worker in the city of Edo, which was built of wood and prone to fires.
“Half of the samurai class were women,” Buckland tells the Independent’s Maira Butt. “There’s a woman’s robe and her daily hair regimen instruments, a dressing set and a hand mirror, and a book of etiquette.”
In the mid-19th century, globalization set the end of the samurai in motion. The system of feudal domains was dismantled in 1871, and the wearing of swords in public was banned in 1876.
But even after the collapse of the samurai class, the image of these warriors was too deeply ingrained in the popular imagination to die out. “So much of the samurai story, including the word itself, was reworked long after their power had waned,” writes Artnet.
Many of the samurai depictions of the past 100 years are relatively benign, albeit very incomplete, ranging from films to video game characters to manga books. Among the most well-known examples of borrowed samurai culture in the West is the costume design for George Lucas’ infamous intergalactic villain Darth Vader. The “Samurai” exhibition contains an original Vader costume, on loan from Lucasfilm, the flared helmet of which was inspired by the neck guards, or shikoro, of samurai armor.
Quick fact: Kylo Ren’s helmet
The Star Wars villain Kylo Ren (played by Adam Driver) wore a helmet “with jagged red lines evoking the traditional Japanese repair technique of kintsugi,” which gave his costume “visual resonances of Darth Vader,” according to the British Museum.
At other times, samurai myths were co-opted for more sinister means. Among the darker artifacts in “Samurai” is a 1937 copy of the book Die Samurai: Ritter des Reiches in Ehre und Treue (The Samurai: Knights of the Empire in Honor and Loyalty), the foreword of which was written by Heinrich Himmler, the Nazi architect behind the Final Solution. To the Axis powers of World War II, the “samurai spirit” was an easily manipulated concept to promote national allegiance.
It is exactly these kinds of modern interpretations of samurai history and legend, the ones that muddle the true story, that the British Museum hopes visitors will consider as they explore the artifacts. As Buckland says in a statement, “This is the first exhibition to interrogate the myth, right through to the present day.”
“Samurai” is on display at the British Museum in London through May 4, 2026.

articles.content:
You Can Buy Jack Kerouac’s Early Draft of ‘On the Road,’ Which He Typed on a 121-Foot-Long Scroll
The author taped pages together so he wouldn’t need to load paper into his typewriter. The original scroll of the Beat Generation classic is expected to fetch up to $4 million at auction
The draft of one of the Beat Generation’s most defining works is heading to auction next month at Christie’s, where it is expected to sell for between $2.5 million and $4 million.
Jack Kerouac’s On the Road, published nearly 70 years ago, is a classic that weaves together travel, American culture and self-discovery, all while enveloped in the burgeoning jazz scene of the late 1940s. Along with works like Allen Ginsberg’s “Howl” and William S. Burroughs’ Naked Lunch, On the Road is considered a pillar of Beat literature. In 2005, Time magazine named it one of the 100 best English-language novels published since 1923.
The book’s unique draft is a scroll measuring 121 feet long. It reflects the plot’s maverick mood and Kerouac’s intrepid writing style. Known to type at roughly 100 words per minute, the author despised the disruption of replacing papers in a typewriter. Instead, he opted to use scrolls—or, more often, makeshift scrolls fashioned by taping papers together—to keep his hands up to speed with his mind.
“This is the original and only scroll for the first draft of Kerouac’s masterpiece,” Heather Weintraub, specialist in Christie’s books and manuscripts department, tells the Guardian’s Emma Loffhagen. “It’s widely considered to be the most iconic artifact of the Beat Generation, one of the most celebrated artifacts in American literature. … When you roll it out, it actually looks like a road.”
Legend has it that Kerouac wrote the entire book in just three weeks—a story that stems from the writer himself, who said as much during an interview with talk show host Steve Allen.
“And so this gave the impression that Jack just spontaneously wrote this book in three weeks,” John Sampas, Kerouac’s brother-in-law, told NPR’s Andrea Shea in 2007. “I think what Jack should’ve said was, ‘I typed it up in three weeks.’”
In reality, On the Road was crafted in meticulous fashion over several years. Kerouac’s journals between 1947 and 1949 contain early drafts of the book, which he voraciously typed up in April 1951. But he also wrote around six more drafts between 1951 and 1957, when he was shopping the book to editors.
Fun fact: The beginnings of On the Road
Jack Kerouac referenced the book by name in a 1948 journal entry: “I have another novel in mind—On the Road—which I keep thinking about: two guys hitchhiking to California in search of something they don’t really find, and losing themselves on the road, coming all the way back hopeful of something else.”
“Kerouac cultivated this myth that he was this spontaneous prose man, and that everything that he ever put down was never changed, and that’s not true,” Paul Marion, a Kerouac scholar, told NPR. “He was really a supreme craftsman, and devoted to writing and the writing process.”
In 2001, the scroll was purchased at auction for $2.4 million by Jim Irsay, the owner of the NFL’s Indianapolis Colts, who died last May. That auction was subject to scrutiny from some of Kerouac’s acquaintances, who believed his materials should remain in the public eye.
After the scroll’s acquisition, Irsay loaned it frequently for exhibitions. Ahead of the March auction, it will be displayed in New York City.
On the Road isn’t the only Kerouac artifact up for sale in March. The original typescript scroll of the author’s novel The Dharma Bums, published in 1958, is expected to sell for between $300,000 and $500,000. Additionally, the first-edition copy of The Dharma Bums owned by Hunter S. Thompson is expected to sell for between $2,000 and $3,000, per Fine Books & Collections.
Other big-ticket items at auction, all from Irsay’s collection, include the guitar Nirvana’s Kurt Cobain used to record the albums Nevermind and In Utero; Jerry Garcia’s “Tiger” guitar, used during his last performance with the Grateful Dead in 1995; the saddle worn by Secretariat during the famous horse’s 1973 Triple Crown win; and a golden ticket used in the production of the 1971 film Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.

articles.content:
Astronomers Spot a Huge Cluster of Galaxies Forming Earlier in Cosmic History Than Thought Possible
The young galaxy cluster existed about 12.8 billion years ago and has an estimated mass 20 trillion times that of the sun
Astronomers have witnessed the earliest gathering of galaxies ever seen, taking place about 12.8 billion years ago. The observations, made by NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) and Chandra X-ray Observatory, suggest that large structures in the universe called galaxy clusters could have formed much earlier than previously thought possible.
The findings were published in the journal Nature on January 28.
“A galaxy cluster is, as the name suggests, an assembly of galaxies, typically hundreds to several thousands. These galaxies are embedded in a halo of hot gas heated to millions of degrees, and the whole system is bound together by dark matter,” says study co-author Ákos Bogdán, an astrophysicist at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian (CfA), to Will Dunham at Reuters.
Dark matter is the mysterious, hard-to-detect material that makes up about 85 percent of the universe’s matter, and galaxy clusters can help researchers better understand the strange stuff. Witnessing when and how these objects grow is “like watching an assembly line make a car, rather than just trying to figure out how a car works by looking at the finished product,” says study co-author Gerrit Schellenberger, also an astrophysicist at CfA, in a statement.
JWST allows astronomers to peer back in time because it can detect far-off celestial objects from long ago whose light took billions of years to reach the instrument. For the new study, Bogdán and his colleagues examined data on an object called JADES-ID1. JWST previously spotted it in a survey, and researchers thought it might be an extremely old galaxy “protocluster,” a cluster in the earliest phase of formation.
This telescope, along with Chandra, revealed that JADES-ID1 has the two key properties of a protocluster: many potential galaxies, at least 66 in this case, bound together by gravity, and a gargantuan cloud of hot gas. The object is 20 trillion times more massive than the sun, the researchers estimate.
What’s more, the protocluster dates to about one billion years after the Big Bang, which happened around 13.8 billion years ago. But many current computer simulations of cosmic history predict that at that point, the universe lacked enough time and galaxies to produce a protocluster of JADES-ID1’s mass.
“Our findings provide further evidence for a more rapid growth of cosmic structure than is predicted by current cosmological models,” Schellenberger says to Reuters. The previous earliest object of this variety was seen about three billion years after the universe’s birth.
Did you know? Oldest known galaxy
Researchers recently spotted the farthest—and therefore oldest—galaxy ever seen. Called MoM-z14, it existed merely 280 million years after the universe began.
“It’s true we don’t understand fully how such structures can form and appear so advanced so early in time,” Klaus Dolag, a computational astrophysicist at Ludwig Maximilian University Munich who was not part of the work, tells Scientific American’s Lee Billings. His past computer simulations suggest that the huge, old protocluster may have slowed its growth as it aged into today’s universe.
Still, learning more about what’s going on with JADES-ID1 is crucial, Dolag says: “Either we learn something new about the complex interplay of various physical processes shaping the formation of galaxies—or we learn there is indeed a flaw in our general background model of cosmology, causing us to oversimplify.”
